The RMP Submittal has been developed for restart of the ammonia refrigeration system at the 800 Ellen Trout Dr. facility.  A previous RMP submittal was done under Armour Eckrich Meats LLC when it owned this facility; however, the facility was shut down and deregistered and has since been purchased by Holmes Smokehouse. The information presented here is for a new prevention program developed for this facility to accurately reflect current system conditions.  Old information such as "date of last compliance audit" that are not applicable to this new owner, have been deleted.









Holmes Smokehouse, located in Lufkin, Texas, processes sausage and packages meat products. The ammonia refrigeration system is a utility system supporting the plant by providing space conditioning and product cooling for meat processing, raw and finished products. The system also provides cooling to generate chilled water through a flooded heat exchanger. Ammonia contained within the refrigeration system is a regulated substance under both the EPA and OSHA regulations. At Holmes Smokehouse the maximum inventory of ammonia exceeds the regulatory threshold of 10,000 pounds.



Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies



Holmes Smokehouse is committed to protecting the public, its employees, and the environment from any accidental releases of hazardous materials used at its facilities. We have implemented safety, environmental protection, and risk management programs to prevent hazardous materials releases.



 If there is an accidental release, we will immediately call for emergency response to minimize the effect of the release and notify the public of any actions necessary to ensure public protection via the San Antonio Fire Department. 



Worst-Case Release Scenario



Holmes Smokehouse has conducted an offsite consequence analysis as required by the EPA regulations, including an extremely unlikely, worst-case release scenario (i.e., total release from the single la

rgest container over a ten minute period, assuming worst case meteorological conditions). Results of this worst-case event indicate that offsite receptors would be affected.



This type of release is not considered credible from the standpoint that an event of this nature would require the catastrophic failure of the container, resulting in a sudden release of the entire contents over a ten minute period. The ammonia system components are designed to withstand pressures well in excess of normal operating conditions and Holmes Smokehouse maintains a very rigorous maintenance and prevention program for all ammonia process equipment.



In fact, EPA release reporting databases and industry experience suggest that the worst-case release scenario as defined in the RMP regulations is so unlikely that it should not be used as the basis for emergency planning. A more reasonable potential release scenario for emergency planning is presented in "The alternative release scenario(s)" section below.



Alternative Release Scenario



A "credible worst-case" scenario, formulated in accordance with USEPA guidance, was selected as the Holmes Smokehouse alternative release scenario. This scenario involves a one-inch diameter hole from a break in the high pressure liquid ammonia piping on the roof of the facility. Results of this credible worst-case event indicate that there are some offsite receptors that would be affected.



The results of the process hazard analysis (PHA) and the facility's operating history suggest that even this credible worst-case is extremely unlikely to occur, but it can serve as the basis for emergency planning.

If such a release did occur, plant personnel would contact the Lufkin Fire Department, who would dispatch specially trained personnel to the facility.



Planned Changes and Maintaining A Safe Operation



While there are no planned major facility modifications, Holmes Smokehouse is continuing to implement hazard analysis and program performance assurance measures to maintain a safe operation. Holmes Smokehouse continually works to safely manage the hazards of anhydrous ammonia to protect the community we serve and the employees working for us. The Risk Management Program will be maintained to reduce the risk of accidental releases and each year we will conduct training, review procedures, maintain the equipment and follow safe work practices. Periodically, we will audit our program, review our Process Hazard Analysis, and coordinate with the community emergency response organization.
